results_summary: Cryo-immunotherapy significantly increased median overall survival (32 months) compared to cryotherapy alone (17.5 months) or no treatment (3 months). Multiple cryo-immunotherapy treatments yielded better survival (36.5 months) than a single treatment (21 months).
population_specificity: 45 patients with metastatic hepatocellular cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of diode laser treatment versus cryotherapy in reducing unfavorable structural outcomes of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found that laser treatment replaced cryotherapy from 2005 to 2012, leading to a reduction in unfavorable structural outcomes of ROP from 13% to 5.6%, though this change was not statistically significant. Cryotherapy was not directly evaluated for efficacy or safety in this study.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with birthweight <1500 g or <32 weeks' gestational age, born between 1 Jan 2000 and 31 August 2012.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of cryotherapy with other treatments (MAL-PDT, 5-FU) for Bowen's disease, focusing on lesion clearance and recurrence rates.
results_summary: Cryotherapy showed no statistically significant difference in clearance rates or recurrences at 1 year compared to 5-FU. MAL-PDT was significantly more effective than cryotherapy in lesion clearance.
population_specificity: Patients with histologically proven Bowen's disease (total of 363 participants across 9 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of ATRA-loaded microneedle patches as an alternative to traditional surgical treatments like cryotherapy for seborrheic keratosis.
results_summary: The study did not directly assess cryotherapy but focused on the efficacy and safety of ATRA-loaded microneedle patches, which showed promising results in inducing epidermal hyperplasia and accelerating stratum corneum turnover.
population_specificity: HR-1 hairless mice and humans (safety study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of cryotherapy as a treatment modality for prostate and renal cancer, including its mechanisms of action and associated risks.
results_summary: The study highlights cryotherapy as a minimally invasive and effective treatment for prostate and renal cancer, with less morbidity than conventional surgery, but does not provide detailed efficacy or safety data.
population_specificity: Patients with prostate and renal malignancies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whole-body cryotherapy (-110°C for 4 min) and cold water immersion (8°C) on knee skin temperature and determine if either achieved a temperature (<13°C) believed necessary for analgesia.
results_summary: Both treatments significantly reduced knee skin temperature, with whole-body cryotherapy showing lower temperatures immediately post-treatment, but cold water immersion maintained lower temperatures from 10-60 min post-treatment. Neither method achieved the target temperature for analgesia.
effective_dosage: 4 min of -110°C whole-body cryotherapy vs. 8°C cold water immersion.
study_duration: Single session with measurements up to 60 min post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the literature on focal therapy (including cryotherapy) for prostate cancer, evaluating its baseline characteristics, preoperative evaluation, and perioperative, functional, and disease control outcomes.
results_summary: Focal therapy showed promising perioperative, functional, and disease control outcomes in short- to medium-term follow-up, with high rates of pad-free continence (95-100%) and absence of clinically significant cancer (83-100%) in treatment-naïve prostates, though efficacy was lower in salvage cases. The review highlighted the need for robust comparative effectiveness studies.
population_specificity: Men with biopsy-proven prostate cancer, primarily low and intermediate risk, with some high-risk cases having unilateral disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of cryotherapy as a focal therapy for localized prostate cancer, focusing on minimizing damage to non-cancerous tissue while maintaining cancer control.
results_summary: The study found that cryotherapy, as part of focal therapy, showed encouraging functional outcomes with low rates of urinary incontinence and erectile dysfunction, but robust medium- and long-term cancer control outcomes are still lacking.
population_specificity: Patients with localized prostate cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize current literature on the oncologic efficacy and toxicity profile of salvage cryotherapy for prostate cancer recurrence after definitive radiation.
results_summary: The study found 5-year biochemical control rates for cryotherapy were in the range of 52%-56%, similar to other salvage treatments, though patient selection and failure definitions varied. Toxicity profiles were distinct compared to other local salvage modalities.
population_specificity: Men with biopsy-proven local recurrence after definitive radiation for prostate cancer, localized disease at presentation, prostate-specific antigen < 10 at recurrence, life expectancy >10 years, and negative metastatic workup.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the beneficial and harmful effects of cryotherapy versus conventional surgery or no intervention in patients with liver metastases.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in mortality or liver recurrence between cryotherapy and conventional surgery groups, though cryotherapy showed slightly higher survival rates at 3, 5, and 10 years. Postoperative pain was more common in the cryotherapy group, but other complications were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with solitary or multiple unilobar or bilobar liver metastases, primarily from colorectal, stomach, breast, and other cancers.
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 5 months to 10 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and compare the histologic transmurality of lesions caused by different energy sources, including cryoablation, in a cadaveric heart model.
results_summary: Cryotherapy achieved a 90% success rate in creating transmural lesions, significantly higher than radiofrequency (33%) and ultrasound (25%). The average length and proportion of transmurality for cryoablation were 11.1 ± 1.1 mm and 35 ± 5%, respectively.
population_specificity: Cadaveric human hearts with an ischemic time of 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the literature on management options, including Cryotherapy, for biochemical recurrence after primary treatment for localized prostate cancer.
results_summary: Cryotherapy was identified as one of the options for local salvage therapy after primary radiation, but comparative assessment among salvage treatments was difficult due to varying definitions of recurrence and patient risk profiles. The role of salvage treatment after radiation therapy, including Cryotherapy, remains unclear.
population_specificity: Men with recurrent prostate cancer after primary treatment (e.g., radical prostatectomy or radiation therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether localized air-pulsed cryotherapy (-30°C) could improve the recovery of neuromuscular function after strenuous eccentric exercise.
results_summary: Cryotherapy delayed local edema formation and muscle activity decline in the medio-distal biceps brachii but did not improve long-term muscle performance recovery. No significant differences were found in maximal isometric torque, DOMS, electromyographic activity, creatine kinase activity, or overall T2 levels between groups.
population_specificity: 24 participants (divided into control and cryotherapy groups) performing maximal isokinetic eccentric contractions of elbow flexors.
effective_dosage: 3 × 4-minute applications at -30°C, separated by 1 minute, administered immediately post-exercise and 1, 2, and 3 days after.
study_duration: 3 days (with follow-up assessments up to 14 days post-exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the implementation of VIA screening and cryotherapy for cervical cancer prevention in Indonesia and identify lessons for national scale-up.
results_summary: The study found that 83.1% of VIA-positive women sought cryotherapy, with 13% treated the same day as screening and 74% treated within 1 month (mean interval: 7.2 days). The project screened 24.4% of the target female population.
population_specificity: Women aged 30-50 in Indonesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the advantages of cancer image visibility using multiparametric transrectal ultrasonography (TRUS) for identifying candidates for focal cryotherapy in prostate cancer.
results_summary: TRUS-guided targeted biopsies significantly improved cancer detection and staging, identifying higher-grade and larger-volume cancers compared to non-targeted biopsies. TRUS-visible lesions showed greater cancer involvement and higher Gleason scores, aiding in better candidate selection for focal therapy.
population_specificity: 93 potential candidates for focal cryotherapy, with 73 eventually considered for hemi-ablative focal cryosurgery (low- to intermediate-risk prostate cancer patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and tolerability of cryotherapy with other topical agents for treating actinic keratoses (AK).
results_summary: Cryotherapy was found to be efficacious in treating AK but less tolerable than imiquimod cream, particularly at lower concentrations. Newer agents like diclofenac gel and ingenol mebutate appeared more tolerable, though comparative efficacy studies were lacking.
population_specificity: Patients with actinic keratoses (AK).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate treatment options, including cryotherapy, for renal cell carcinoma (RCC) in the elderly population, balancing therapeutic benefits with safety and quality of life.
results_summary: The abstract mentions cryotherapy as an alternative ablative therapy for localized RCC, but does not provide specific efficacy data. It highlights the need to consider patient-specific factors like age and comorbidities when choosing treatments.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with localized or metastatic renal cell carcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to qualitatively evaluate the effects of cryotherapy on the clinical outcomes and quality of life in fibromyalgia patients.
results_summary: Fibromyalgia patients treated with cryotherapy showed a more pronounced improvement in quality of life compared to non-treated patients, as measured by standardized health status scales. The improvement is speculated to result from cryotherapy's regulation of pro- and anti-inflammatory mediators involved in pain modulation.
population_specificity: 100 fibromyalgia patients aged 17-70 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of whole-body cryotherapy (WBC) on biochemical, pain, and performance parameters during recovery after hamstring-damaging exercise.
results_summary: The study found that WBC showed a significant interaction for rate of torque development and substantial differences in pain measures compared to the control, but results did not strongly support WBC for recovery enhancement.
population_specificity: Participants undergoing hamstring-damaging exercise (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Single 3-min daily exposures to temperatures between -140 to -19 °C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term safety and efficacy of liquid nitrogen spray cryotherapy in eradicating high-grade dysplasia (HGD) and intestinal metaplasia (IM) in patients with Barrett's esophagus (BE-HGD).
results_summary: Cryotherapy achieved 100% eradication of HGD and 84% eradication of IM at 2-year follow-up, with durable responses and low recurrence rates. No serious adverse events occurred, though strictures were noted in 9% of patients, all successfully treated.
population_specificity: 32 patients with BE-HGD of any length.
effective_dosage: Liquid nitrogen spray cryotherapy every 8 weeks until complete eradication was confirmed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of MRI guidance in focal ablation therapies, including cryotherapy, for prostate cancer, focusing on device positioning, thermal monitoring, and tissue depiction.
results_summary: MRI guidance effectively positioned ablative devices, monitored thermal ablation (threshold of 52°C), and accurately depicted ablated prostate tissue, which was resorbed at 30 days. The study highlighted MRI's potential benefits in focal prostate cancer ablation but noted challenges in cancer identification for targeting.
population_specificity: Canine model (in vivo)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relative efficacy of cryotherapy compared to other treatments for actinic keratosis (AK) using a network meta-analysis.
results_summary: Cryotherapy was ranked lower in efficacy compared to 5-FU, ALA-PDT, IMI, IMB, and MAL-PDT but higher than DCF/HA and placebo for participant complete clearance in AK treatment. The ranking was based on Bayesian network analysis of randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Nonimmunosuppressed participants with actinic keratosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical features, treatment outcomes, and recurrence rates of conjunctival papilloma in different age groups, including the use of cryotherapy.
results_summary: Cryotherapy, often combined with excisional biopsy, showed satisfactory tumor control, with recurrence rates higher in children and adolescents (15%) compared to adults (1%). The study did not isolate cryotherapy's standalone efficacy but noted its role in combination treatments.
population_specificity: 10 children and adolescents (≤20 years) and 63 adults (>20 years) with conjunctival papilloma.
study_duration: Mean follow-up of 24 months for children/adolescents and 38 months for adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of cryotherapy as part of a protocolised treatment for pain intensity, range of motion, and functional status in patients with Subacromial Impingement Syndrome.
results_summary: Cryotherapy was part of a combined treatment protocol, but the study did not isolate its individual effects. The intervention group showed significant improvements in function and external rotation movements, but no significant differences were found in pain intensity. Patient satisfaction was higher in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Patients with Subacromial Impingement Syndrome (n = 120) in Spanish National Health Service Primary Health Care Centres.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of whole-body cryotherapy (WBCT) on mental state parameters in patients with spinal pain syndromes or peripheral joint disease, considering age, gender, and illness severity.
results_summary: WBCT significantly improved WHOQOL-Bref and PGWBI scores, with stronger effects on mood and well-being than quality of life. The therapy was most effective in women, patients with spinal pain, and those with severe depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: 55 patients (43 women, 12 men) aged 20-70 with spinal pain syndromes (n=34) or peripheral joint disease (n=21).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not specified (only session count provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether HPV type influences the natural course and treatment response of common and plantar warts to cryotherapy, salicylic acid, or a wait-and-see policy.
results_summary: Cryotherapy showed high cure rates for HPV 2/27/57-associated common warts (68%) and HPV 1-associated plantar warts (65%), but low efficacy for HPV 2/27/57-associated plantar warts (11%). HPV type significantly impacted treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with new common or plantar warts recruited from 30 Dutch family practices (n=250).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence for early post-operative cryotherapy as part of the continuum of care for elective total hip and knee replacement surgery.
results_summary: The study identified early post-operative cryotherapy as one of the aspects reviewed, but heterogeneity in the evidence precluded specific recommendations. No detailed findings on cryotherapy's effects were provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing elective total hip (THR) and knee (TKR) replacement surgery.

study_goal: The researchers were comparing different treatment modalities for gingival de-pigmentation, including cryotherapy, but focused on scalpel surgery and electrosurgery in the reported cases.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results for cryotherapy, as the study focused on scalpel surgery and electrosurgery, which showed pleasing aesthetic results and uneventful healing.
population_specificity: Patients with gingival pigmentation complaints (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term prospects of percutaneous cryotherapy for treating benign or malignant soft tissue tumours.
results_summary: The study found cryotherapy shows potential for local tumour control, analgesic efficacy, reduced complications, and shorter convalescence periods, though evidence is based on small populations.
population_specificity: Patients with benign or malignant soft tissue tumours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the state of art for destructive and topical treatment options, including cryotherapy, for actinic keratoses (AKs) based on randomized trials meeting specific criteria.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that cryotherapy is among the treatment options reviewed, with response rates measured as complete remission, but specific efficacy data for cryotherapy alone are not detailed. The study highlights the need for comprehensive overviews to avoid biased perspectives on therapeutic approaches.
population_specificity: Individuals with actinic keratoses (AKs), likely including those with varying grades and locations of lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of cryotherapy as an ablative therapy for Barrett's esophagus, particularly in high-risk situations like high-grade dysplasia.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that cryotherapy produces mucosal necrosis through freezing tissue, suggesting it is a viable ablative therapy. It is mentioned alongside other effective endoscopic therapies for Barrett's esophagus, though specific efficacy data for cryotherapy alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with Barrett's esophagus, particularly those with high-grade dysplasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of endoscopic therapies, including cryotherapy, for treating low-risk T1a esophageal adenocarcinoma.
results_summary: Cryotherapy was used in 9% of patients as part of ablative therapy, achieving complete remission from cancer in 96% of cases, but specific outcomes for cryotherapy alone were not detailed. The overall treatment approach was safe and effective, with no deaths related to esophageal cancer.
population_specificity: Patients with low-risk T1a esophageal adenocarcinoma treated at a tertiary-care center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate alternative treatments for pyogenic granuloma, including cryotherapy, compared to surgical excision and imiquimod cream.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that cryotherapy, among other alternative treatments, may require multiple sessions, pose unwanted complications, and have the highest rate of recurrence for pyogenic granuloma. No specific efficacy data for cryotherapy is provided.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients and young people with pyogenic granuloma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a conservative treatment approach, including cryotherapy, for psammomatoid juvenile ossifying fibroma in a pediatric patient.
results_summary: The study found that cryotherapy, combined with curettage, was effective in treating the fibroma without relapse during the first year of therapy, suggesting a potential benefit of conservative treatment in pediatric cases.
population_specificity: A 4-year-old male patient with psammomatoid juvenile ossifying fibroma.
study_duration: First year of therapy (exact duration of cryotherapy not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and complications of 70% TCA application versus erbium: YAG laser ablation for treating xanthelasma palpebrarum (XP) lesions.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in improvement or complication rates between 70% TCA application and erbium: YAG laser ablation for XP lesions. Both methods showed similar effectiveness and safety profiles.
population_specificity: 21 patients (1 male, 20 females) aged 22-70 years with XP lesions.
effective_dosage: Not specified for cryotherapy (study focused on 70% TCA and erbium: YAG laser).
study_duration: Evaluation performed 4 weeks after the first treatment session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) in detecting prostate cancer (PCa) and indirectly compared it to modern treatments like HIFU and cryotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that TURP detected PCa in 65% of patients, suggesting its potential utility in selected cases with rising PSA and negative biopsies. The data also reinforced the need for whole-gland treatment using modalities like HIFU and cryotherapy.
population_specificity: 106 patients undergoing HIFU therapy without neoadjuvant treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare cryoablation (CA) and radiofrequency ablation (RFA) as treatment options for renal cortical neoplasms, focusing on their feasibility and viability as alternatives to partial nephrectomy.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that both CA and RFA are feasible and viable alternatives to partial nephrectomy for treating renal cortical neoplasms, though specific comparative outcomes are not detailed. The study emphasizes the importance of understanding how these technologies achieve cellular destruction.
population_specificity: Patients with incidentally discovered renal cortical neoplasms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of intralesional antimony (IL Sb) and cryotherapy against placebo for treating single lesions caused by Bolivian Leishmania (v.) braziliensis.
results_summary: Cryotherapy showed a low cure rate of 20%, significantly lower than IL Sb (70%) and similar to placebo (17%). Adverse effects were not specifically reported for cryotherapy, but the treatment was less effective than IL Sb.
population_specificity: Patients with single lesions due to Bolivian Leishmania (v.) braziliensis.
effective_dosage: Cryotherapy was administered on days 1 and 14.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and effectiveness of cryotherapy for treating HPV-positive women in remote and transient populations as part of a cervical cancer screening program.
results_summary: Cryotherapy was successfully administered to HPV-positive women after VIA triage, with 87% returning for evaluation and treatment. At 6-month follow-up, 74% returned, and 3 cases of CIN 2 were identified, all from endocervical samples.
population_specificity: Women in remote and transient populations in Peru (Manchay and Iquitos).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the epidemiology, clinical presentation, and recent advances in the management of benign skin neoplasms, including cryotherapy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about cryotherapy's effects, only mentioning it as one of multiple available therapies for benign skin neoplasms.
population_specificity: Not specified (general mention of benign skin neoplasms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review controversies and management strategies for open-globe injuries, including the use of prophylactic cryotherapy.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that the use of prophylactic cryotherapy is practiced differently worldwide, indicating unresolved debate but does not provide specific findings on its effects.
population_specificity: Patients with open-globe injuries (OGIs), including pediatric cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of cryotherapy in treating HR-HPV-positive women, both with and without VIA-positive results, following triage.
results_summary: Cryotherapy was administered to 291 women, but the abstract does not detail specific outcomes or efficacy metrics for cryotherapy alone. The study highlights the high sensitivity and specificity of HPV testing methods but lacks detailed cryotherapy results.
population_specificity: Women aged 30-50 years in rural Mexico, nonpregnant, with no history of hysterectomy or pelvic irradiation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of daily multiple applications of cryotherapy (ice) on exercise-induced muscle damage (EIMD) over a 72-hour recovery period, using a protocol resembling current clinical practice.
results_summary: Cryotherapy significantly reduced pain at 48 hours post-EIMD compared to the control group, but no significant differences were found in other measures (isometric torque, hamstring length, or biochemical markers). The cryotherapy group showed non-significant trends toward improved range of motion and lower creatine kinase (CK) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels at 72 hours.
population_specificity: 33 subjects (23 in the cryotherapy group, 10 controls) with induced EIMD in the right hamstring muscle group.
effective_dosage: Ice applied immediately post-EIMD and thrice daily for 20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of salvage endoscopic therapies, including spray cryotherapy, for recurrent esophageal cancer after concurrent chemoradiotherapy.
results_summary: Endoscopic spray cryotherapy showed a complete response rate of 37.5% in treating recurrent esophageal cancer, though data on long-term outcomes and comparative effectiveness were limited.
population_specificity: Patients with recurrent esophageal cancer limited to the superficial esophageal wall or those unfit for salvage esophagectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the current and future importance of cryotherapy for localized prostate cancer.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about cryotherapy's effects, only mentioning its increasing use alongside other focal therapy techniques.
population_specificity: Men with clinically localized prostate cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare tendinopathies in inflammatory vs. non-inflammatory rheumatic disorders and outline a conservative management framework, including cryotherapy.
results_summary: The abstract mentions cryotherapy as part of the management for tendinopathies but does not provide specific results on its effectiveness. It highlights pain as a common symptom and the need for conservative treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory and non-inflammatory rheumatic disorders affecting the foot and ankle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of double-modality therapy (cryotherapy and phonophoresis) versus single treatments (phonophoresis or cryotherapy alone) in managing pain from musculoskeletal injuries.
results_summary: The study found that cryotherapy, phonophoresis, and double-modality therapy were equally effective in reducing pain, with no significant difference in treatment sessions required. However, double-modality therapy might achieve pain relief in fewer sessions for over 90% of subjects.
population_specificity: 60 subjects with musculoskeletal injuries.
study_duration: Treatment administered on alternate days until pain-free (1-5 sessions per subject).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of intravitreal bevacizumab plus ablative therapy (including cryotherapy) versus ablative therapy alone for treating Coats' disease.
results_summary: The study found that cryotherapy alone failed in two patients, while the combination of bevacizumab and thermal ablation (including cryotherapy) successfully treated all severe cases. However, the bevacizumab group required more treatments over a longer period.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with Coats' disease treated by a single surgeon from 2001 to 2010.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an updated and comprehensive estimate of the efficacy, safety, and acceptability of cryotherapy for treating cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN).
results_summary: Cryotherapy achieved high cure rates (94.0% for CIN1, 92.0% for CIN2, and 85.0% for CIN3), with minimal complications reported. The double-freeze method and absence of endocervical involvement significantly improved cure rates.
population_specificity: Patients with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN).
effective_dosage: Not specified (freezing method described as single or double-freeze).
study_duration: Follow-up duration varied but was included in the meta-analysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of therapeutic interventions, including cryotherapy, for anal canal intraepithelial neoplasia (AIN).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for cryotherapy, as the only RCT included compared imiquimod versus placebo, finding no statistically significant efficacy.
population_specificity: HIV-positive men who have sex with men (MSM), HIV-negative MSM, immunosuppressed patients, and individuals with HPV-related conditions like genital warts and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and cosmetic outcomes of cryotherapy with other treatments, particularly photodynamic therapy (PDT), for actinic keratoses.
results_summary: The study found that photodynamic therapy (PDT) was more effective and had better cosmetic outcomes than cryotherapy for individual lesions. Cryotherapy was less effective compared to ALA-PDT (RR 1.31, 95% CI 1.05 to 1.64).
population_specificity: Participants with actinic keratoses, a skin condition caused by long-term sun exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes and toxicity of local salvage therapies, including cryotherapy, for recurrent prostate cancer after failed primary external beam radiotherapy (EBRT).
results_summary: The study found that salvage cryotherapy may provide long-term local control in selected patients, but toxicity is often significant. Data on cryotherapy outcomes and toxicity vary widely due to heterogeneous patient populations and treatment techniques.
population_specificity: Patients with locally recurrent prostate cancer after primary EBRT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of panretinal photocoagulation (PRP) combined with intravitreal bevacizumab (IVB) and cryoretinopexy (CR-IVB) versus PRP with IVB alone in treating neovascular glaucoma (NVG).
results_summary: The study found that PRP combined with CR-IVB resulted in significantly better intraocular pressure (IOP) control at 12 months compared to PRP with IVB alone, with success rates of 80.0% vs. 41.7% in open-angle NVG and 22.7% vs. 0% in angle-closure NVG. Cryotherapy enhanced the effectiveness of PRP for NVG for at least one year.
population_specificity: Patients with neovascular glaucoma (NVG) due to proliferative diabetic retinopathy, central retinal vein occlusion, or ocular ischemic syndrome (mean age 59.6 ± 11.5 years).
effective_dosage: 1.25 mg/0.05 ml of IVB combined with 360° of cryotherapy of the peripheral retina.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of partial matrixectomy using cryotherapy versus electrocautery for treating ingrown nails in stages 2 or 3.
results_summary: Cryotherapy was successful in 20 of 24 patients (83.3%), showing comparable efficacy to electrocautery (62.1%). No significant difference in relapse rates was observed between the two methods.
population_specificity: Patients aged 11-79 years (median 31.8 ± 16.9) with stage 2 or 3 ingrown nails.

study_goal: The researchers reviewed the efficacy of cryotherapy as a provider-administered treatment for genital warts, comparing it to other treatments.
results_summary: Cryotherapy is listed as a provider-administered treatment for genital warts with a high primary clearance rate, though recurrence after successful treatment remains at 30-40%. The abstract does not provide specific efficacy data for cryotherapy alone but groups it with other treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with genital warts (HPV-associated conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the benefits and harms of cryotherapy for localized prostate cancer compared to other treatment options.
results_summary: The abstract states that further studies of cryotherapy are needed to determine its benefits and harms, indicating insufficient data for conclusive results.
population_specificity: Men with localized prostate cancer (primarily over 65 years of age).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of advanced imaging techniques in diagnosing and managing intraocular vascular tumours, including the use of cryotherapy as one of several ablation options.
results_summary: The abstract mentions cryotherapy as an option for ablating intraocular vascular tumours but does not provide specific results regarding its effectiveness compared to other treatments. Secondary effects of treatments, including those from cryotherapy, are noted but not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with intraocular vascular tumours (e.g., choroidal haemangiomas, retinal haemangioblastomas).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of cryotherapy in treating ocular tumours, particularly in cases where other modalities like radiotherapy or surgery are considered.
results_summary: Cryotherapy is mentioned as a treatment option for discrete retinoblastoma, though it is noted to be ineffective for larger tumours or those with vitreous seeds, where plaque therapy or proton therapy may be preferred. The abstract does not provide detailed outcomes specific to cryotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients with ocular tumours, including retinoblastoma, conjunctival squamous carcinoma, and malignant melanoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of cryotherapy as an adjunct to endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) and endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) in managing early esophageal cancer and reducing synchronous/metachronous lesions in Barrett's esophagus.
results_summary: The study found that cryotherapy is an effective adjunct to EMR and ESD, reducing the occurrence of synchronous and metachronous lesions in Barrett's esophagus. It supports endoscopic therapy as a primary management method for early esophageal cancer.
population_specificity: Patients with early esophageal cancer or Barrett's esophagus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of cryotherapy among conservative treatment options for localized retinoblastoma, focusing on eye and visual function salvage.
results_summary: The abstract mentions cryotherapy as one of several effective conservative treatments for localized retinoblastoma, but specific outcomes or comparative efficacy data for cryotherapy alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Children with localized intraocular retinoblastoma, particularly those with bilateral cases (40% of patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of ultrasound-guided cryoablation for treating fibroadenomas in an office setting.
results_summary: The study found that cryoablation effectively reduced fibroadenoma volume and palpability, with 91.3% of cases showing complete ice ball engulfment and 96% of patients and physicians rating cosmetic results as excellent or good. Minor adverse events occurred in four cases, but no serious complications were reported.
population_specificity: Young women with histologically confirmed benign fibroadenomas up to 3 cm in size.
effective_dosage: Not specified (freeze-thaw-freeze cycle based on fibroadenoma size).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 1 week, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year post-procedure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whole body cryotherapy (WBC) at -110°C and cold water immersion (CWI) at 8°C on muscle, skin, and core temperature reductions.
results_summary: Both WBC and CWI significantly reduced muscle and core temperatures, with similar effects observed 60 minutes post-treatment. WBC caused a greater immediate reduction in skin temperature compared to CWI.
population_specificity: Twenty active male subjects.
effective_dosage: 4-minute exposure for both WBC and CWI.
study_duration: Single 4-minute session per treatment, with a minimum 7-day washout period between treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two physical therapy programs, one including cryotherapy, on nursing professionals with rotator cuff disorder, focusing on quality of life, work satisfaction, and pain intensity.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant pain reduction, but only the experimental group (with proprioception exercises) showed significant improvement in quality of life. No significant difference was found between the two treatments.
population_specificity: Nursing professionals with rotator cuff disorder.
study_duration: Data sampling occurred between June 2010 and July 2011, but exact intervention duration is not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a cryopneumatic device on post-operative recovery after total knee arthroplasty (TKA), focusing on range of motion, functional testing, narcotic consumption, and patient satisfaction.
results_summary: The study found that the cryopneumatic device significantly reduced narcotic consumption compared to ice with static compression during the first two weeks post-operation, with a trend toward improved walking distance at six weeks. Patient satisfaction was significantly higher with the cryopneumatic device, but no significant differences were observed in range of motion, functional tests, or knee girth between the groups.
population_specificity: 280 patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty at 11 international sites.
effective_dosage: Cryopneumatic device or ice with static compression used at least four times per day.
study_duration: Two weeks of active intervention, with follow-up assessments at six weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined cyclic compression and cryotherapy (Game Ready System) reduces postoperative complications, pain, and recovery time in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found that intermittent cryocompression reduced postoperative blood loss and showed trends toward lower morphine usage, shorter hospital stays, and less wound discharge, though no significant difference in postoperative pain scores was observed. One deep venous thrombosis event occurred in the control group, but no adverse events were reported in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Thirty patients (mean age 68 years, range 31-83) undergoing elective hip arthroplasty for end-stage osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Intermittent cryocompression therapy administered 15 times for 30 minutes each.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but intervention was applied postoperatively during hospital admission.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide a comprehensive overview of nonsurgical treatment modalities for nonmelanoma skin cancer, including cryotherapy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about cryotherapy's effects, only mentioning it as one of several nonsurgical treatment options for NMSC.
population_specificity: Patients with nonmelanoma skin cancer (basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma).

study_goal: The abstract does not focus on evaluating Cryotherapy specifically; it primarily examines the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy combined with an exercise program for shoulder pain.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on Cryotherapy's effects, as it is mentioned only as one of several therapeutic modalities used in conservative treatment.
population_specificity: Adults with shoulder pain caused by conditions like Subacromial impingement syndrome, rotator-cuff tendinitis, or biceps tendinitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate treatment preferences for skin cancer, including the frequency and effectiveness of cryotherapy compared to other nonsurgical options.
results_summary: Cryotherapy was the most common nonsurgical treatment option (52.4%) for skin cancer, particularly for actinic keratosis, where nonsurgical treatments were more frequent than surgery. Despite the availability of conservative treatments, cryotherapy remained widely used.
population_specificity: Patients with skin cancer (basal cell carcinoma, actinic keratosis, squamous cell carcinoma, cutaneous malignant melanoma, and Bowen disease) from eight European countries.
